questions.question: How does Fortify work?
questions.answer: Fortify is a locally installed application that listens on a known TCP port. Web applications use the Fortify WebCrypto polyfill to communicate with this application which enables the web application to use smart cards, security tokens and locally installed certificates.â€¨

questions.question: Fortify is running but the web application says the server is offline, what do I do?
questions.answer:
Web applications communicate with fortifying over a special network address known as 127.0.0.1 or localhost. Sometimes host based firewalls or proxy configurations will prevent this communication from taking place.

If you have either of these configured you can try to disable them temporarily and see if it enables the session to be established. Alternatively, you can just add exceptions to allow communications to 127.0.0.1 and try again.

questions.question: What Browsers does Fortify support?
questions.answer: IE 11, Edge, Safari, Firefox, and Chrome

questions.question: What Operating Systems does Fortify support?
questions.answer: maxOS 10.12 or greater, Windows 7 and later
